headline: Manuel Ugarte terms agreed, Ivan Toney signs - Man United dream end to transfer window
body: Manchester United have done the heavy lifting when it comes to their recruitment drive this summer.

However, with nine days remaining for Premier League clubs to strike up further business, there might yet be more to come from Ineos and key figures behind the scenes. United are still in the market for another midfielder and their prime candidate - as it has been for several weeks - is Manuel Ugarte from PSG.

It was thought that the proposed deal was dependent on outgoings - which are still being considered - but United are 'open' to a late change in approach for the Uruguay regular. The Manchester Evening News understands a loan with the option to buy could be priced-up to help them get Ugarte over the line before August 30.

United are, meanwhile, prepared to sell five more players including Jadon Sancho this summer. Here, our dedicated reporters take a look at what could happen around Old Trafford between now and next Friday night's deadline, and offer up their dream scenarios for the closing days;

Manuel Ugarte is a deal which needs to happen for United to call this transfer window a success. The midfielder could be United's most important signing of the summer and the difference between them finishing in the top four or not.

Whilst Casemiro has looked better in the early stages of 2024/25, the 32-year-old cannot be relied upon for another season. After signing Ugarte, United's next priority should be selling several players who don't have a long-term future at Old Trafford, starting with Jadon Sancho.

Victor Lindelof is another player who should go, although with his current injury that seems unlikely, whilst Christian Eriksen won't be much use this season. Scott McTominay may be worth keeping though, providing it doesn't impact a deal for Ugarte.

The Scotland international proved his worth for Ten Hag's team last season and still remains a useful squad player. What United don't want though is keeping someone who doesn't want to be there which may necessitate a sale, regardless of how much he still offers.

Heading into these final stages of the summer transfer window, United should have a clear goal in mind - signing a midfielder. To finance this, the Reds will more than likely need to sell McTominay which, for the right price, would be good business.

If United can receive their valuation of £40m they will be laughing at that and considering the panic in the Napoli camp at present, this could well be doable too. After bringing in the money for the Scottish central player it is more than likely that Ugarte will be added to the team.

The jury is out on the Uruguayan at present but there is still plenty of time for him to reach the heights needed to be a starter for United. Once again, the big issue here will be regarding his price tag with a loan move perhaps the wisest decision for now.

After that, I am not sure that United would need to do any more business or be in a position to do any more for that matter. Sancho's sale is not necessarily the priority it once was and if the hatchet has well and truly been buried, there is no reason why he could not be a force this season.
A loan deal for Manuel Ugarte looks to be on the cards for United in between now and the end of the transfer window. That signing would fill the position where the United squad are most in need.

Getting the deal done on an initial loan does mean that funds raised through sales for the move won’t be so important between now and the end of the window. Therefore if no team reaches the £40 million asking price for Scott McTominay, then he will stay at Old Trafford for at least another six months before the situation is looked at again in January.

Another source of income from player sales is Jadon Sancho. While the situation surrounding the public fall-out between him and Ten Hag now looks to have been resolved, it still feels that the player’s future lies away from Old Trafford. United have reportedly set an asking price of around £40 million, if they can get that, it would serve as a boost ahead of the January window.

There’s no real other areas of the squad that obviously need strengthening for the remainder of the season. If the Ugarte signing gets over the line then the concentration should therefore be on outgoings.

On paper, the dream scenario for United between now and 11pm on August 30 is rather simple. However, due to complex deals taking shape and one or two players facing uncertain futures at the club, the business that should map out - both in and out of Old Trafford - is anything but straightforward.
A permanent sale for Scott McTominay would enable United to press ahead with Manuel Ugarte.

Amid one or two question marks over his transfer fee, though, Ineos might be better-served following their 'new' plan and signing the Uruguay international on loan instead. That would allow them to keep McTominay around for one final year as his goals would be an additional bonus in a reduced, bit-part role.

Cashing in on Jadon Sancho would be ideal, too, to perhaps allow United to bring in another striker. Ivan Toney is not exactly an essential recruit, but he could be a useful addition to injured Rasmus Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee up top if United feel the need to spend whatever money they get from Sancho on an alternative profile.

United's dream end to the transfer window would start with cashing in on Jadon Sancho and Scott McTominay before reinvesting that income into their defence and midfield. Victor Lindelof should also be off, freeing up his wages more than necessarily a transfer fee.

Manuel Ugarte seems to be who they want, so agreeing to a loan deal with Paris Saint-Germain would be ideal, with an option rather than an obligation to buy the Uruguay international. Then, the dream scenario would be returning for Jarrad Branthwaite and signing the third central defender that the club have been open to signing this summer.

That would represent a complete overhaul of the position and be necessary after offloading Lindelof. Branthwaite, Matthijs de Ligt and Leny Yoro would finally adequately address that problem position in the squad, allowing the new hierarchy to address other areas over the coming windows.

headline: Manchester United are copying Man City transfer trick to beat FFP concerns
body: Facundo Pellistri might no longer be a Manchester United player, but club officials will hope the winger continues to shine as he begins his career away from Old Trafford.

The Uruguayn's permanent exit was confirmed with a £5.1m move to Panathinaikos on Wednesday, with a further £1.7m due in add-ons, but the most eye-catching part of the deal was the size of the sell-on United had negotiated with the Greek outfit.

Whether Pellistri shines or not in Greece, United will pocket 45% of his next fee. If the 21-year-old is sold at a loss that won't amount to much, but if he thrives for regular game time and lands a bigger move, then a substantial sum could be heading back to fill the coffers at Old Trafford. Pellistri will hope to find his way back to a big five European league and United will hope he can achieve that as well.

Sell-on clauses have gradually become more common in the game and United are starting to latch on. Almost all of the deals they have done for the sale of academy players this summer have included sizeable clauses and one will be included when Maxi Oyedele finalises his move to Legia Warsaw.

There was what was described as a 'sizeable' sell-on clause included when Willy Kambwala left to join Villarreal and around a 50% clause included in the deal that took Mason Greenwood to Marseille. United also included a sell-on when Alvaro Fernandez joined Benfica while most agreements also include buy-back clauses.

This is now the common structure when academy graduates are sold and United have made up ground in this department. They have certainly been more proactive around selling young players since Erik ten Hag arrived at the club, with Anthony Elanga, Zidane Iqbal, Matej Kovar, Teden Mengi, Axel Tuanzebe, Ethan Laird, Charlie Savage, Noam Emeran, and Marc Jurado all leaving last summer.

In Ten Hag's first summer in charge James Garner was the headline academy departure, moving to Everton when a 15% sell-on clause was included. United are tending to get higher percentages now and it is sometimes worth accepting a smaller fee to land the higher clause, protecting the club if the player suddenly thrives with exposure to regular football.

United are yet to see a major benefit to these deals, but it's no surprise they are getting higher clauses in deals when two former Manchester City powerbrokers now work for the club, in chief executive Omar Berrada and technical director Jason Wilcox. City lead the way when it comes to profiting from academy sales and often doing so twice.

This summer they banked around £10m from the deals that took Aro Muric from Burnley to Ipswich and Douglas Luiz from Aston Villa to Juventus. They could cash-in again if James Trafford is sold by Burnley and collected twice in quick succession last year when Romeo Lavia left Southampton to sign for Chelsea.

In an era defined by stricter spending controls, buy-back clauses are becoming a key weapon for big clubs. United have had to sell to buy this summer and could yet be forced to sell Scott McTominay to raise the funds to sign Manuel Ugarte.
The £40m or so they have raised from selling Greenwood, Kambwala, Pellistri and Fernandez has been helpful, but the fees heading to United for that quartet won't end there.

headline: Gareth Southgate lands new role after England exit and Man United links
body: Gareth Southgate, the former England head coach, has taken up a new role with UEFA, less than two months after his departure from the national team.

The 53-year-old ended his eight-year tenure with England following Euro 2024. In recent months, even before his exit from the England job was announced, Southgate's name had been linked to several positions, including Manchester United prior to Erik ten Hag signing a new contract extension at Old Trafford.

Reports now suggest that Southgate has accepted a new position that will last until the end of the season. Meanwhile, Henry Winter claims he will be attending matches as a UEFA technical observer, alongside ex-West Ham United manager David Moyes.

Technical observers are responsible for analysing matches from a coaching viewpoint and producing comprehensive reports with video and statistical analysis. They have access to multiple camera angles, cutting-edge visualisation tools, and a wealth of data to aid their observations.
The role also involves identifying trends in football play, providing coaches and coach educators with a more holistic understanding of the game.

Roberto Martinez, previously a UEFA technical observer, shared insights with the organisation's official website, saying: "Instead of just watching the game for a specific reason, in my capacity as a national team coach, you are watching it in a more holistic way and appreciating the development of the game and the competition itself.

"It could be different types of performances, from young players, for example, or the way the competition is getting tougher physically and cuter tactically with the new trends within the competition."
Several managers and ex-managers served as technical observers at Euro 2024, including Fabio Capello, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, Avram Grant, Aitor Karanka, and Frank de Boer.

Southgate's acceptance of the UEFA role hints that he may not return to club management until after the current season at least. England have yet to announce their next permanent manager, with Lee Carsley stepping in on an interim basis until a successor is appointed.

headline: Erik ten Hag might send £38m message with Manchester United starting XI decision
body: Matthijs de Ligt has Ajax, Juventus, Bayern Munich and Manchester United on his CV.

He's exclusively played for some of Europe's biggest clubs at just 25 years old and arrived in Manchester this summer with the sort of pedigree most footballers dream of having. United signed De Ligt from Bayern Munich for €45m (£38.4m) with a potential further €5m (£4.2m) in add-ons earlier this month and that seemed a reasonable fee.

Considering the experience De Ligt has and the potential upside to his arrival, his transfer seemed like smart business from United. Yet he may have to wait longer than expected to make his full debut for the club because Harry Maguire got the nod against Fulham last week.

De Ligt has been signed to start and the expectation is he will partner Lisandro Martinez, but Maguire started on the opening day and won't give up his place without a fight. Maguire enjoyed a renaissance last term and clawed his way back into the starting side, despite losing the captaincy, which demonstrated his impressive resilience and determination.

The 31-year-old has avoided injury for most of his career and was unfortunate to pick up two separate issues last term, a groin problem in December and April's calf injury. Some questioned the commitment of United's players last term and Wayne Rooney said in May that a few members of the dressing room were hiding behind injury, but that couldn't have been further from the truth with Maguire, who put his body on the line for the club.

United's defenders dropped like flies and Maguire could have opted for a spell on the sidelines to get fully fit when his body was tested in April - but he didn't and continued. Maguire played through a knock away from home against Bournemouth on April 13 and was spotted clutching his left thigh in pain. Although it seemed likely he would be substituted at half-time, he received treatment in the dressing room and emerged for the second period.

United played Coventry in the semi-finals of the FA Cup a week later and Maguire didn't train between games, yet he played 120 minutes and pushed through another issue. He is the type of character who will always be welcome in a United dressing room and his dedication hasn't gone unnoticed by fans, whose relationship with him has healed.

Maguire picked up where he left off against Fulham and was one of United's best players, making crucial interventions when Fulham were close to Andre Onana's goal and seeming to meet every ball that was crossed into the box with his head. It would be wrong to name Maguire on the bench against Brighton on the back of that impressive performance, which means the wait for De Ligt's full debut should go on.

De Ligt was introduced in the second half against Fulham and some fans will prefer him to start over Maguire at the Amex Stadium but it would send the wrong message to the squad. Maguire didn't put a foot wrong and the starting role should be his for as long as he continues to deliver strong performances. If Maguire underperforms then replacing him with De Ligt in the starting XI will be logical but he should start until then.

Understandably, there is a clamour among supporters to see De Ligt start because he is brand new and shiny, but Maguire was excellent last season and won't be displaced easily. He is certainly not a glamorous player but he's dependable. He put an awful two years behind him last season and will make more starts than most expect in 2024/25. The defender has fought for his starting place previously and will do so again.

headline: Noussair Mazraoui arrival might negatively impact Manchester United player who Erik ten Hag loves
body: The Players' Player of the Year award is decided by Manchester United's players and Diogo Dalot was acknowledged by his teammates when he picked up the prize.
"For me, it’s even more special [than the main award]. I have a lot of consideration for the fans; they are a big part of me and the biggest part of this club," said Dalot.

"But my teammates are the ones who see each other every single day. We have to come here and we still have to fight, and we still have to share these moments when things are not going well, and when the things are going well. This, ultimately, is my second family.
"This award is recognition by your team-mates, so I think it’s really special because they see you every day, they know the work that you put in behind the scenes."
Dalot lost his starting role in Erik ten Hag's first year but forced his way back into the starting team in 2023/24 and became one of the most consistent performers in the dressing room.
He started 35 games from a possible 38 in the Premier League and managed to avoid injury throughout the campaign, only being unavailable once through suspension.
Dalot's durability was a huge asset in a season when most players seemed to pick up an injury and he probably played the best football of his career on an individual basis.
Of course, last season was disappointing for United as a club, but Dalot emerged with credit and Aaron Wan-Bissaka was sold this summer, which ended their battle for good.

Noussair Mazraoui has been brought in from Bayern Munich for €15million (£12.8m) with a possible €5m (£4.2m) in add-ons and club sources said he was signed because he is comfortable playing on either side of the defence.
Mazraoui is versatile and that made him an appealing option, especially when considering that Luke Shaw and Tyrell Malacia missed large chunks of last term due to injury.

The Morrocan international started against Fulham on the opening day of the campaign, but it became clear in the warm-up he was playing at right-back and Dalot was starting at left-back because they were preparing for kick-off by playing in crosses from those sides.
Mazraoui made a confident debut and made a vital contribution in the first half when intercepting explosive Fulham winger Adama Traore after his tremendous run on the right.
Traore sprinted down Dalot's channel but he was nowhere to be seen and Mazraoui thwarted the danger by coming across to his side and executing a brilliant slide tackle in the box.
Overall, it was a pleasing first appearance from Mazraoui, but Dalot wasn't at his best on the other side and may struggle to reproduce his strongest displays at left-back.

Thankfully, Shaw should return from the sidelines in a few weeks and Dalot should regain his starting role at right-back, but it seems likely that Shaw will be absent again at different periods this season, which means he may have to play on the other side when necessary.
Dalot has plenty of experience of playing at left-back and featured there on several occasions last season, but his attacking threat is reduced when he doesn't start at right-back.
In the scenario of Shaw being unavailable and Ten Hag preferring Mazraoui on the right side of defence, expectations of Dalot contributing in attacking phases should be lowered.
Dalot is often seen making overlapping runs and crossing the ball using his right foot when he starts there and he's unable to be as effective when starting on the opposite side.
It's something worth keeping in mind when assessing Dalot's performances in the coming weeks.

headline: Manchester United are nearing the perfect squad size in the transfer market
body: Another incentive for Manchester United to prioritise sales over the next eight days is their squad size.
The club website lists 32 players in the first team section. It is not as obese as Chelsea's squad but there is some flab to cut off.
There are caveats. Dan Gore, last in a matchday squad in December and recovering from a shoulder injury following an unfulfilling loan at Port Vale, is listed as a first team squad member.
Harry Amass, Toby Collyer and Ethan Wheatley were added earlier this month and the trio all started for the Under-21s in their captivating comeback at Barnsley in the EFL Trophy on Tuesday night.

Facundo Pellistri is going and Hannibal Mejbri probably will go. In the best-case scenario that Scott McTominay and Jadon Sancho are also among the outgoings with Manuel Ugarte the incoming, then United would have a healthy squad size of 28.

Clubs with European competition commitments to factor into their calendars need 25-man squads, minimum. United tend to favour that number and make allowances for academy breakthroughs. Wheatley became academy debutant 250 in April and Collyer was the 251st. Amass should be the 252nd.

In 2016-17, United eventually settled on a 28-man squad (with the re-addition of Bastian Schweinsteiger) as they won the Europa League. The drawback was there was only one rookie bidding to breakthrough in Axel Tuanzebe, so Morgan Schneiderlin and Memphis Depay knocked on Jose Mourinho's door asking to leave long before the winter transfer window opened.

Both left after only 18 months at United and so did Schweinsteiger two months later. Players started to drop like flies, with four on crutches for the Europa League final. Mourinho turned to the academy to supplement the squad and Tuanzebe was a regular in the run-in while Scott McTominay was promoted in a 64-game campaign.

United have 38 Premier League games, at least eight Europa League league matches, League Cup and FA Cup third round ties this term. That is 48 matches minimum - only four shy of the 52 fixtures they had in the exhausting 2023-24.

Erik ten Hag has three specialist left backs having gone the majority of last season without any. The two senior options are still crocked but Diogo Dalot is a secure stop-gap and Ten Hag believes Amass could be ready for competitive first team exposure in the spring.

"We have to make progress," Ten Hag said at UCLA on August 1. "But we all see here a potential where we have seen in previous years, for instance two years ago, Garnacho last season. We had it during last season with Kobbie.
"But he (Amass) is not that far now at this moment. But if we train him well, if we coach him well, then in three months it's possible that he can be on that point."

"But in this moment he needs to catch up and he has to develop some skills already to play for Manchester United, competing for the highest positions in the league. But with big talent it can go up very quickly and that is very interesting to see if he is capable of doing this."

Collyer has been named in both squads this season and is likely to be on the bench again at former club Brighton on Saturday. Wheatley could get more matchday involvement on Europa League nights when benches are expanded to 12 substitutes.

There is ample cover in defence, even with two centre halves on crutches. Four centre backs played against Fulham and United will almost certainly have Victor Lindelof as an option when he is fit again.

United would rather have Jarrad Branthwaite yet Lindelof's injury-ravaged pre-season leaves them saddled with a player they could have released this summer had United not triggered the one-year extension in Lindelof's deal.
Five of the six injuries United have already suffered this season have been to defenders. Aaron Wan-Bissaka has gone and the small-fry Will Fish is bound for Cardiff.

United's midfield and attack were seldom depleted last season. For the nadir at Crystal Palace in May, United fielded an attacking trio that cost £218.3million. There are two obvious picks for each of the front four positions.

The issue last season was United effectively had one striker to depend on and Rasmus Hojlund, an unproven and callow striker signing, missed nine matches. United lost four of them and Hojlund's muscle injury on the eve of the visit of Fulham in February was the death knell for their Champions League qualifying chances. Fulham beat United and then City did the following week.

United have creditably coped in their past five matches with a strikerless side and a substitute striker. Hojlund came on to score against Newcastle and Brighton while Joshua Zirkzee was the matchwinning debutant against Fulham.
After the September internationals, Hojlund and Zirkzee should be in the same matchday 20, with the squad a healthier size.

headline: Swap deal, PSG option, £40m 'approach' - Jadon Sancho Man United transfer latest
body: Jadon Sancho has been reintegrated at Manchester United by Erik ten Hag this summer.

However, the former Borussia Dortmund winger, who returned to Signal Iduna Park on loan in January following a public spat with his United manager, still faces an uncertain future. But will he stay or go?

The clock is ticking for him to pursue a switch elsewhere, while clubs across the Premier League have until August 30 to strike up business and most top-flight divisions in Europe fall into the same direction. Here, we take a look at the latest news and headlines surrounding the 24-year-old and his future.
A few eyebrows were raised when reports from Germany flagged up Sancho as a potential target for Chelsea this summer. Those claims were subsequently backed up by The Athletic.
Chelsea have money and, seemingly, will spend. The Blues rubber-stamped a transfer for Joao Felix and are said to be willing to make a late approach for Sancho before August 30 comes and goes.
It comes amid a proposed fire sale at Stamford Bridge as key figures upstairs attempt to generate some more cash for their own recruitment drive. Sancho is tipped to cost around £40million.
PSG have long-since been mooted with interest. It has even been claimed Sancho could be used as the bargaining chip to help United sign prime midfield target Manuel Ugarte.
Several options appear to be on the table in that pursuit. Reports from The Independent pinpointed a swap deal to appease both clubs - with Sancho initially moving to Paris on loan.

An agreement to that tune is described as unlikely, although United need to ease PSR concerns to help them push forward with plans to sign Ugarte as cover and competition for Casemiro in their engine room. Sancho is 'willing' to join PSG this summer, at least as per that article.
Amid all the uncertainty, United do have a clear plan for Sancho this summer.

The Manchester Evening News understands United are 'open' to selling the player and four others before deadline day rolls around, while they would equally accept a 'fitting' loan proposal. Will Fish, Hannibal, Scott McTominay and departing Facundo Pellistri are also up for grabs.

headline: Napoli stance, £23m offer, Manuel Ugarte need - Scott McTominay Man United transfer latest
body: Scott McTominay is a man in demand amid uncertainty over his Manchester United future.

The 27-year-old is wanted by Napoli - and United are open to a sale - but Fulham have stepped back in the chase to sign him. McTominay has been inked-in for a proposed transfer this summer - although the Scotland midfielder would still be regarded as a first-team player if Ineos are unable to sanction another outgoing.

The clock is ticking for him to pursue a switch elsewhere, while clubs across the Premier League have until August 30 to strike up business and most top-flight divisions in Europe fall into the same direction. Here, we take a look at the latest news and headlines surrounding McTominay and his future.
United-linked Sander Berge has signed for Fulham. Effectively, that successful pursuit for a midfielder means the Cottagers are highly-likely to 'give up' on McTominay.
Fulham made three bids for the Scotland international this summer. However, their final offer was worth £23million and United are understood to be holding out for £30million to sanction a move.
McTominay, 27, has 12 months left to run on his contract at Old Trafford, although the club does hold an option with that agreement. Napoli are said to be interested in his services.

McTominay holds the key for United between now and the August 30 deadline. In their ongoing chase for Manuel Ugarte - or another holding midfielder - Ineos must generate funds, while McTominay is (inadvertently) responsible for what else might be possible in their recruitment drive.

The Manchester Evening News understands United are 'open' to selling the player and four others before deadline day rolls around; Will Fish, Hannibal and Jadon Sancho are also up for grabs, while Facundo Pellistri has now signed for Panathinaikos after the club accepted an offer worth £5.1million.

Reports from The Times have flagged up McTominay as a main target for Napoli this summer. However, the Italian side are said to be keen on a loan deal - amid limitations with their budget - while United would, seemingly, prefer a permanent agreement to be struck up for him.
Interest has been addressed directly by the three-time Scudetto winners. Napoli sporting director Giovanni Manna was pressed on McTominay before their Serie A opener.

Manna said: "They [McTominay and Brighton's Billy Gilmour] are good, strong players. Let's see what happens over the next few days. It's useless to make forward momentum today [when] there's the game and after the game, we will think about the transfer market."
McTominay has totted-up 254 appearances for United. Despite his availability, Erik ten Hag would alternatively be happy to keep him at the club if no agreement is reached.

headline: Manchester United include 16-year-old in first-team training after scoring two wonder goals
body: Jim Thwaites trained with Manchester United's first-team at Carrington on Wednesday, despite being just 16 years old.

The highly regarded Thwaites was among the academy players drafted into the session to make up numbers ahead of facing Brighton, with his inclusion feeling significant given his age. Thwaites is considered as one of the academy's leading prospects in his age group and won the club's Goal of the Season award for both Under-16 and Under-18 level last term.

The youngster's goal for the U18s was particularly important because it provided a late equaliser against Derby in added time. The U18s drew that game 2-2 thanks to Thwaites' goal in the dying seconds and his strike ensured their unbeaten record in the league continued.
The U18s' unbeaten run in the league was eventually ended - they lost just two games all season - but they still strolled to the title, finishing six points ahead of Manchester City.

The youngsters scored 78 goals during their winning Premier League North campaign and it's understood coaching staff at City acknowledged United's quality. City's U18s had won the league for four successive seasons and their staff privately conceded United had been a cut above last term.

Thwaites predominantly played for the U16s last season, but he made nine appearances for the U18s and was given two substitute appearances for the Under-21s. He is expected to be given a prominent role in Adam Lawrence's U18 side this season and the opportunity to join in with first-team training on Wednesday was recognition of his progress.

headline: 'They will be' - Pep Guardiola explains what Manchester United's four new signings will bring
body: Pep Guardiola believes Manchester United's four new signings will provide momentum and help Erik ten Hag to steer his side into the Premier League top four this season.

United have signed Joshua Zirkzee, Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui this summer and are looking to sign a midfielder before the transfer deadline on August 30. Mazraoui made his full debut in the 1-0 victory against Fulham on Friday and Zirkzee scored the matchwinner from off the bench.

De Ligt was also introduced to the game as a substitute and those new arrivals all played their part in claiming three points on the opening day of the season. Yoro was unveiled to the Old Trafford crowd before the game and he stood on crutches following a successful surgery on the metatarsal injury that he sustained in pre-season.

The young defender, who was signed from Lille for an initial €62m, is expected to return to action in October and will attempt to help United qualify for Champions League football again. That is the minimum target for Ten Hag and Guardiola recently told reporters he expects United to be in contention for top four and to have 'momentum' after their summer transfers.

“Always at the beginning of the season, the first target is to finish in the top four,” Guardiola said about the tough competition in the Premier League this season. “People say: ‘Oh, come on’, I say ‘no’. Newcastle are not in Europe, and are going to play one game a week. Newcastle with one game a week this season will be the Newcastle of two seasons ago.
“Arsenal are not necessary to talk about. Liverpool are not necessary to talk about. I know the signings of United, they are going to take the momentum and they will be there.
“Tottenham, I’m pretty sure they invest and with the young players and the manager knows better. There are a lot of teams - Chelsea again, the amount of players and their quality and the manager.

“Six or seven teams will be there and if you drop a little bit, you will be away. This is the reality that I have felt since the first season I arrived here and after we proved to ourselves that we can do it and to try to do it again. It’s simple.”

United finished eighth in the Premier League last term, which represented their worst finish in the top flight, and were eight points adrift from the Champions League places. The bookmakers have made City, Arsenal, Liverpool and United their favourites to finish in the top four, with Chelsea and Tottenham priced as the most likely after that.
Aston Villa qualified for the Champions League last season but many expect Unai Emery's side to drop off, just like Newcastle did after playing in Europe's premium competition.

headline: Ruud van Nistelrooy shows Manchester United true colours with three-word verdict of Fulham win
body: Manchester United assistant coach and former striker Ruud van Nistelrooy has given the club's win in the opening match of the season his own seal of approval after Joshua Zirkzee's late winner secured all three points against Fulham on Friday night.

United were hoping to get their third season under manager Erik ten Hag off to a positive start but it took until the 87th minute for them to truly get going after a myriad of missed opportunities for both sides went begging.

Zirkzee started the move, picking the ball up in the Fulham half before playing it out to Casemiro on the right-hand side. The Brazilian found Alejandro Garnacho whose cross was then expertly poked home by United's new centre-forward, who sent Old Trafford into raptures.

After the game, Zirkzee highlighted his delight with his debut goal, claiming it was: "A great feeling, a great feeling, it couldn’t be any better. What can I say? Debut, winning, scoring in front of the Stretford End, so yeah, it’s unbelievable. Where does this moment rank?

"Somewhere between my debuts and it’s a bit below winning the Champions League with Bayern and my national team debut, but it’s up there. I'm just trying to be the best version I can be, help the team and club, so no specific goals."

Afterwards, Van Nistelrooy was spotted putting his arm around the new United frontman with a huge smile on his face, clearly highlighting his delight with Zirkzee's finish. Posting to social media platform Instagram, Van Nistelrooy then shared a photo of him in the dressing room as well as one of the Old Trafford tunnel which leads out onto the pitch.
The Dutchman posted the two photos alongside the caption: "Great team performance, +3" with red, white and black heart emojis.

headline: Manuel Ugarte to Man United transfer reality has already been explained by player's agent
body: Manuel Ugarte's agent Jorge Chijane has previously admitted that he's sure the Uruguayan will leave Paris Saint-Germain this summer.

Manchester United are interested in signing the midfielder after agreeing personal terms last month. However, the sticking point is agreeing a transfer fee with PSG who reportedly value Ugarte at £51million.

The 23-year-old has since been left out of Luis Enrique's squad for PSG's opening game of the Ligue 1 season against Le Havre on Friday. That has led to increased speculation that a move to Old Trafford could soon happen with United in need of midfield reinforcements amid uncertainty over Scott Mctominay's future and Casemiro's struggles.

Ugarte is signed to Jorge Mendes' agency, Gestifute, with the Portuguese flying into London last week, reportedly as part of talks over his client's future. But his agent Chijane has already told O Jogo back in May that the Uruguay international is unlikely to stay in Paris.
"There is much talk, but I am still not sure about the club. There are many possibilities on the table," he said.
"It’s almost certain that he won’t stay, it’s sure he’ll leave. I believe the situation will be resolved."

The midfielder shone for Sporting CP two seasons again in the Champions League but has struggled to make an impact in France. Ugarte's struggles in Paris should be of some concern but he shouldn't be written off after one poor season.

Ugarte was also one of the standout players at the Copa America this summer with his performances playing a key role in Uruguay reaching the semi-finals. If a reasonable fee can be agreed with PSG then it's certainly a gamble worth taking.

Defensive midfield was at the heart of a lot of United's problems last season with age and injuries appearing to have caught up with a labouring Casemiro. The Brazilian has been linked with a move to Saudi Arabia and Ugarte could be a perfect replacement.

headline: Gary Neville tells Man United exactly why they should sign Ivan Toney after Brentford snub
body: Gary Neville has admitted that he wants Ivan Toney to stay in the Premier League amid transfer links to Saudi Arabia. The striker has been linked with Manchester United this summer as well as Chelsea and Arsenal.

Earlier this month, it was reported that Saudi Arabia club Al Ahli were keen to bring him to the Saudi Pro League. Toney is now in the final 12 months of his contract at Brentford and looks certain to depart.

After Joshua Zirkzee was signed by United earlier in the window, it was expected that their interest in the England international had cooled. However, an injury to Rasmus Hojlund has meant the Red Devils remain in the market for his signature.

On Sunday, the 28-year-old was left out of Brentford's squad for their 2-1 Premier League win over Crystal Palace. The striker is understood to be fully fit with Thomas Frank confirming his absence was down to transfer interest.
"A lot of things going on with Ivan, there is some transfer interest," Frank told Sky Sports. "Because of that he is not in the squad.
"Ivan is a top player we all know that. He has been a fantastic player for us for four years but we showed last year we could cope without him."

Brentford are expected to prefer to sell the England forward now instead of sanctioning a loan move. Neville, who was speaking on Sky Sports after Toney's exclusion, insisted that his arrival would be an asset to any Premier League club.
"I'd love to see him stay in the Premier League but I've been told he may be going to Saudi Arabia, which would be a shame," he explained.

"In the Premier League, we've enjoyed watching him in the last few years but he probably feels like he needs to exploit this contract more than any other before. He's not had the career of a lot of players have had at his age who play for England, where they'll be earning big money.
"He'll feel like he's got to go and earn the [most] money that he possibly can so he may do that. I'd love him to stay in the PL, he'd be a great asset for another club."

headline: Manchester United receive major blow ahead of transfer deadline as player spotted on crutches
body: Manchester United defender Victor Lindelof was absent from the squad to face Fulham on the opening day of the new season and has been pictured using crutches.
Lindelof wasn't included in the squad for the Community Shield or the 1-0 victory against Fulham on Friday night and last appeared in the final pre-season friendly of the USA tour.
The Swedish international, who has entered the final year of his contract, started against Liverpool in South Carolina on August 4 and was substituted at half-time with a knock.

"Always, we have to see what's going on, the assessment. With Will Fish, it's an impact injury, but we also had to sub at half-time, Jonny Evans, because he was ill. Victor Lindelof was a precaution. So yeah, there are some injuries, but we have to see how bad it will be," said Erik ten Hag.

On Thursday, Ten Hag provided a team news update when he spoke at his press conference at Carrington ahead of facing Fulham, but he didn't clarify Lindelof's injury situation. However, the player's wife, Maja Nilsson Lindelof, has shared a photo of him using a crutch on Instagram with the caption: "Doing everything in slow motion these days."

The one-year extension in Lindelof's contract was triggered in December, and United had been actively looking to sell him this summer to obtain a fee before his deal expires. There are 12 days remaining in the transfer window, and Lindelof being spotted with a clutch could have consequences for United's plan to offload him before the deadline.
If United are unable to sell Lindelof in this summer window, he will be allowed to negotiate terms with an overseas club from January and could leave on a free transfer.

Lindelof made 14 Premier League starts last season and slipped down the central defensive pecking order as Harry Maguire returned to form and regained Ten Hag's trust. He has made 249 appearances for United and is one of the longest-serving players in the club's dressing room.

headline: Manchester United send classy message to academy graduate after serious head injury
body: Manchester United have issued a statement in support of their former midfielder Angel Gomes after he was hospitalised due to a severe head injury sustained while playing for French side Lille.

The Reds academy graduate was contesting an aerial ball when he collided with Reims defender Amadou Kone which resulted in his dismissal from the game. Gomes's teammates formed a protective circle around the former United star and fans from both sides chanted his name for a lengthy period.

After being stretchered off, Gomes was transported by ambulance and the match restarted after 34 minutes. United's statement following the incident read: "Everyone at Manchester United is sending best wishes to former Reds midfielder Angel Gomes, who suffered a serious head injury while playing for Lille on Saturday."

Following Lille's update which confirmed he had regained consciousness, United wrote on X: "Sending love and strength to Angel Gomes, who has been taken to hospital following a collision while playing for Lille. We’re thinking of you, Angel."

After the game, Lille manager Bruno Genesio spoke to the media about the incident and delivered an update on Gomes's condition. "The latest news is rather reassuring, but it's better to be careful," he said.
"Angel asked if he was going to play [next] Saturday. It's a good sign if he has a sense of humour. The match was secondary for me tonight. Angel was conscious when he was carried out.
"I know he spoke, he asked about the result, he showed he's in good spirits, but I think we have to wait a bit."
Lille went on to win 2-0 and after the match, his teammates posed with a shirt adorning the message: 'Courage Angel'.

Gomes left United in 2020, joining the French club before spending a season on loan in Portugal, with Boavista. Despite being hailed as one of the most promising talents of this century by United's academy staff, he struggled to secure a regular spot at the senior level at Old Trafford.
