headline: New role, dream partnership - How Manuel Ugarte transfer can unlock three Man United stars
body: Manchester United are looking to bring defensive midfielder Manuel Ugarte into their team before the end of the summer transfer window next week.

The Uruguayan midfielder comes with big expectations to meet in the centre, particularly after last season's woes in the middle of the park. Too often United found themselves cut open with the mix-and-match central defenders left unprotected from the attacking hordes.

Casemiro was often blamed as being off the pace in the midfield which forced United to lack a defensively minded player in the centre. Upon his arrival at Old Trafford, you would expect Ugarte to form a partnership with Kobbie Mainoo.

During the summer, we saw how Mainoo blossomed alongside Declan Rice for England at the European Championships and having a player who can effectively mop up in front of the back line should allow Mainoo to roam forward and show off his attacking capabilities. One person who is confident Ugarte can produce this role is former United striker Diego Forlan.

He told ESPN Uruguay last year that he had spotted the midfielder's potential early and expressed: "He is very important in the middle to free Valverde and Bentancur. Defensively he adds a lot. If I were a coach, I would love to put Ugarte in the middle."
Having that anchor in the centre should not only allow Mainoo a bit more freedom but also give captain Bruno Fernandes the opportunity to focus solely on his offensive work.

While both Rasmus Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee are showing promise with the latter happy to drop deep to start a build-up and link-up play, the Reds need a player like Fernandes to showcase his creativity. He should not be preoccupied with defensive duties - this should be left to Mainoo and Ugarte.

Having Fernandes dictating play in the upper third of the pitch should not only help the young centre-forwards but also bring into play Marcus Rashford who is on a journey to rediscover his form. At his worst, Rashford looks isolated on the left flank but with Fernandes given more freedom to create, there is an opportunity there for the winger to be reintroduced into the attack more regularly.

headline: Manchester United announce new contract for exciting winger who travelled on USA tour
body: Manchester United youngster Sam Mather has signed a new long-term contract with the club.
Mather's previous deal expired in June 2025, meaning he'd entered the final year of his contract, and he's now signed fresh terms that will ensure his future beyond next summer.
The youngster, 19, was brought to the United States for the first-team's pre-season tour this summer and spent time with Rochdale on a flexi-loan in the second half of 2023/24.

United created a flexi-loan system last year, which allows youngsters to gain senior experience whilst remaining involved in the day-to-day environment at Carrington, and Mather scored twice in 10 appearances for Rochdale, who finished in midtable in the National League.
Mather was increasingly present in United first-team training before signing for Rochdale on a flexi-loan and his contract deal is a reward for his continued progress in the academy.
Mather started every game in the successful 2021/22 FA Youth Cup campaign and contributed three goals and two assists on the way to winning that trophy.
From that crop of players, Alejandro Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo are now established first-team players, while Dan Gore and Charlie McNeill have been given senior debuts.
Shortly after the Youth Cup triumph, Mather was sidelined with a long-term injury, but he returned to full fitness last term and was in great form in academy fixtures.
He caught attention when scoring four goals for the U21s in a 4-2 win over Norwich at Old Trafford in January, and finished last season with seven goals in 10 academy appearances.

headline: Man United get Ben Chilwell transfer green light as major £51m exit hint dropped
body: Manchester United got off to a winning start after a debut goal for Joshua Zirkzee earned a 1-0 triumph over Fulham.

It was by no means a gold standard performance from Erik ten Hag's side but they did enough to pick up their first win of the season - extending their formidable run on the opening day of the Premier League season.

United can sit back and relax for the rest of the weekend and watch the action unfold throughout the English top-flight as the likes of Liverpool, Manchester City, Arsenal, Chelsea and other contenders look to get off to winning starts.

Friday night saw a host of debuts with Noussair Mazraoui starting at right-back after signing from Bayern Munich this week. Match-winner Zirkzee and Matthijs de Ligt were second-half substitutes with the defender brought on in the latter stages to see the game out with Harry Maguire taken off as a precaution. With all that said, MEN Sport takes a look below at some of the latest media reports surrounding United as well as a view on each one...

"This morning we had 22 players training and if you ask all of them they want to play against City on Sunday but that is impossible," Chelsea manager Enzo Maresca said speaking ahead of Sunday's clash with reigning champions, City.

"When you train every day and not get any minutes it is not good for them or for me and I need to make a decision. Probably it is better to leave and go and get minutes. The transfer window is open so we will see what will happen."

According to BBC Sport, the new Chelsea manager has told England defender Ben Chilwell that he can leave the club this summer. The full-back has suffered with injury problems since arriving at Stamford Bridge.
And earlier this summer, Man United were linked with a move for the full-back. It was claimed that United were considering an approach for the left-back to bolster their full-back options.

MEN says: Friday night saw another makeshift left-back as Diogo Dalot was forced to filter over to that side while the new arrival started in the position on the right. Injuries have ravaged through United's ranks in the position with Luke Shaw and Tyrell Malacia on the treatment table and while there is a timeframe, there is always the challenge of getting up to speed with the Premier League intensity as well as forcing the returnee back is likely to spark more issues.
Chelsea's willingness to sell Chilwell could put United on alert as he may be available at a bargain price. With that being said, there is always a concern with the defender's injury record.
Paris Saint-Germain midfielder Manuel Ugarte was left out of the squad for their opening day win over Le Havre.
The Parisiens' curtain-raiser coincided with United's opener against Fulham but the Uruguayan was forced to watch on as PSG earned a commanding 4-1 win.

United have held an interest in the midfielder with the Ligue 1 giants open to selling the former Sporting CP man for €60million (£51m) but it appears that there is still a distance between the clubs coming to an agreement. Nevertheless, there will be some encouragement as he was left out of the squad as interest swirls.

Casemiro started against Fulham but the scrutiny will not be far away from the former Real Madrid midfielder following his showings last term. headline: I missed a penalty for Manchester United - Sir Alex Ferguson then gave me the silent treatment
body: Having made light work of Newcastle United in their opening Premier League fixture of the 2010/11 campaign, winning 3-0 at Old Trafford, Manchester United travelled to the capital the following weekend with ambitions of scooping another three points.

Goals from Dimitar Berbatov, Darren Fletcher and Ryan Giggs had sealed a comfortable opening day triumph over the Magpies at Old Trafford and a road trip to Craven Cottage looked like another enticing opportunity to get maximum points on the board.
Having taken an 11th-minute lead through Paul Scholes, United's army of travelling supporters in the Putney End were confident of enjoying another comfortable afternoon watching their team.

However, Fulham, who were under the stewardship of Roy Hodgson at the time, hit back 12 minutes after half-time through Simon Davies. It was nothing more than what the hosts had deserved and United knew they were locked in a battle for maximum points.

But when Cottagers defender Brede Hangeland turned the ball into his own net with just six minutes of regulation time remaining, United looked on course to preserve their 100 per cent start to the season. Just moments later, the Reds were given a golden opportunity to make sure of the points once and for all.
After Damien Duff sliced his own clearance, the ball struck his own arm. A penalty was awarded and United were given the opportunity to wrap up the game from 12 yards.

Giggs, who had stepped off the substitutes bench a little over 10 minutes earlier, was United's designated penalty taker at the time and looked set to place the ball down on the spot. However, Giggs handed the ball to Nani, who had forced Duff's error to win the spot-kick.

The Portuguese international stepped up and saw his effort saved by Fulham goalkeeper David Stockdale. It was a relatively easy strike for Stockdale to react to, palming it away to his right-hand side.

No doubt preparing himself to face the wrath of Sir Alex Ferguson for his failure to convert from 12 yards, Nani's fears of a tongue-lashing from the former United manager worsened when Hangeland atoned for his error, scoring at the right end in the 89th-minute to earn Fulham a point.

It was an action-packed conclusion to the game that saw Hangeland at the centre of the drama. Whereas the former defender had looked set to leave the hero as a villain, it was Nani who was in the firing line.
"That day he [Ferguson] was so mad at me," Nani said. "But he preferred to kill Giggs, because he had the ball and was the most experienced player on the field.
"But because I was playing so well and I won the penalty, I wanted to score it. Giggs saw that and said 'yeah, take it' – but then I missed.
"When we went to the dressing room, Sir Alex was shouting at Giggs, saying 'Why did you do that?' and then said to me 'Nani, you'll never take penalties anymore'."

As is still the case when United play in London, the squad made the trip back north after the stalemate on the banks of the Thames by train. They alighted the service in Macclesfield - roughly 20 miles south of Manchester - and Ferguson was in need of a lift home.

Living next door to Ferguson at the time, Nani was tasked with the responsibility of chauffeuring the legendary Scot. Having missed from the penalty spot to wrap up three points just hours earlier, the now-37-year-old could have been forgiven for fearing an ear-bashing.

After getting into the car, Nani anticipated a dosage of the infamous hairdryer treatment. Instead, Ferguson did not say a thing.
"When we got off the train, we had to go home, and because Sir Alex was living next to me, someone said 'Can anyone give a ride to the boss?' and I said 'I can, no problem'.

Ferguson evidently held no grudges against Nani for his failure to convert from the spot, rewarding him with a starting berth for United's following game. He scored and provided an assist as they brushed West Ham United aside at Old Trafford, winning 3-0.
The winger, who was often a box of tricks, enjoyed a stellar start to the 2010/11 Premier League campaign, scoring five goals and registering 11 assists in his first 15 appearances of the season.

However, Ferguson stuck to his word and never allowed Nani to step up from the penalty spot again. Fortunately for the former Sporting Lisbon man, he enjoyed enough moments in a United shirt not to rely on a kick from 12 yards.

headline: I watched Man United beat Fulham in 'insane' viral bar that will blow your mind
body: For many football fans, experiencing their team win live in the stadium is one of the greatest joys imaginable.

Plenty of Manchester United fans who were packed into Old Trafford on Friday night as Joshua Zirkzee wheeled away in celebration against Fulham would be of this opinion. However, 14 hours away next to the SoFi Stadium in Inglewood, California where the Reds faced Arsenal in pre-season, the supporters in attendance would beg to differ.

Overnight, the Cosm Experience Bar went viral as images from their venue showcased the action as if you were in the stands yourself. One fan Chigozie (aka Slick Rule on X) from Birmingham was fortunate enough to be at the bar and told MEN Sport about his incredible experience watching the Reds like never before.

"I was actually at work, I live in Birmingham and I came to LA for a work trip," he explained. "In the office we were discussing the Premier League season and someone says there is this nice place that has newly opened, it is close to the SoFi Stadium and they are going to be showing the game.

"I checked it out on my phone and noticed it was ticketed, they had different sections with different price ranges. The most expensive tier was about $100 (£77.86) and that was in a VIP section. The other price point was $22 (£17.13) and for that you could sit anywhere around the screen.

"When you walk in it feels like you are live at the game. You see every detail in the stadium, even the fans. I came to the US last Saturday, I have been to a lot of places - Hollywood and the rest - but this tops my experience in the US for this summer. It was simply amazing."

Chigozie explained that rather than a cinema screen, the bar has installed a dome-like screen which immerses you in the experience. When the action is happening, cameras cut to different angles in the stadium to show you the best possible view of what is happening.

Once at that angle, you could see the entirety of the action across the length of the pitch as the camera positioned you as if you were in the Sir Alex Ferguson Stand or the Stretford End. Unsurprisingly, Chigozie shocked his family and friends when he sent them images and videos of his view of the match on social media.

"I posted a lot of the videos on Twitter and I captioned it with: ‘Here at the executive director’s box at Old Trafford,’ and my friends thought I was back in the UK and were wondering how I managed to get a ticket in the box," he laughed. "They couldn’t believe that I wasn’t actually in Old Trafford."

While he admitted that he would love something like this to come to the UK, there is an acceptance that this could be difficult due to the 3pm blackout rules. "I spoke to one of the US fans about it and I did wonder how possible it would be to have this in the UK considering not all games are available on a matchday," Chigozie concluded.
"But I think if something like this was to come to Birmingham and I could not go to Old Trafford, I think it would be pretty massive."

headline: Man United given £2bn Old Trafford redevelopment verdict as forgotten star sends transfer plea
body: Erik ten Hag will be hoping to further bolster his Manchester United squad before the transfer window slams shut later this month. Dan Ashworth has already welcomed a few new faces to Old Trafford, but he's yet to get his hands on a midfielder.

Manuel Ugarte continues to be heavily linked with a move, meanwhile, Sander Berge has recently emerged as an alternative option. As for outgoings, Scott McTominay still faces an uncertain future despite appearing off the bench against Fulham on Friday night.

The Scotland international is just one of nine players who are set to leave following the expiration of their contract next year. So, with that being said, the Manchester Evening News have rounded up the latest news and transfer gossip on Saturday morning, August 3.

Speaking on the Inside Track podcast, Keith Wyness has insisted Man United will receive no government funding for the redevelopment of Old Trafford despite Sir Jim Ratcliffe's pleas. The former Everton chief said: "Unlike the US, there will be no government funding for a project like this.

"The only funding they will get will be around the changes to infrastructure – roads in the public domain. There really shouldn’t be any investment into a private club’s stadium. It will be up to them to assess the funding model they’re going to have and the size of stadium they’ll go for.

"We’ve been told that 100,000 seats is the target. It seems a sensible target for United, and the financial model should be able to sustain that. Interest rates are coming down globally, so it should be easy for them to get it financed. Even at £2billion, I can’t see it being a problem. If they reduce the numbers, it won’t be due to a lack of government funding."
The Manchester Evening News says: "Old Trafford is well overdue a new lick of paint, so I'm really intrigued to see what Sir Jim Ratcliffe has planned with regards to a redevelopment."

According to Italian newspaper La Repubblica, as quoted by TeamTalk, Scott McTominay has taken matters into his own hands and told Antonio Conte that he wants to join Napoli this summer. The 27-year-old midfielder has recently entered the final year of his contract at Man United.

The report states that the Italian giants are interested in signing McTominay after wrapping up a deal for Billy Gilmour. TeamTalk add that the Napoli sporting director, Giovanni Manna, has recently travelled to the United Kingdom to secure the Brighton ace's signature – and the United man is in his sights.

The Manchester Evening News says: "As sad as it may be to say goodbye to Scott McTominay, he wants regular game time – like any player would. Unfortunately, the Scotsman won't get that under Erik ten Hag – especially if Man United plan to bring in another midfielder before the deadline later this month."

According to Italian outlet Gianluca Di Marzio, Fiorentina are interested in signing Victor Lindelof. The 30-year-old defender faces an uncertain future at Man United following the arrivals of Leny Yoro and Matthijs de Ligt this summer.

The report states that the Serie A club are exploring the possible conditions of a move for Lindelof, who sees his contract at Old Trafford expire next year. Di Marzio adds that Raffaele Palladino wants to sign a new defender after signing Moise Kean, a striker, Andrea Colpani, a winger, Albert Gudmundsson, an attacking midfielder, and David De Gea, a goalkeeper.

The Manchester Evening News says: "Like Scott McTominay, Victor Lindelof will just want to find a club that can offer him regular first-team football. With the Swede's contract set to expire soon too, Man United must cash in on him now before it's too late and he leaves for free."

headline: Man United make Manuel Ugarte transfer decision amid Luke Shaw replacement search update
body: Manchester United are reportedly set to step up their pursuit for Manuel Ugarte over the weekend and into next week.

The Paris Saint-Germain midfielder still remains a top target for the club but as it stands, there has been a gap between the two sides when it comes to a valuation. Football Insider reports United are pushing to agree a deal with the French giants with a view to advancing talks to sign Ugarte.

It is widely reported the Uruguay international is keen to join United and PSG head coach Luis Enrique has reportedly decided Ugarte is not in his plans. Ugarte was left out of Enrique's 21-man team for their Ligue 1 opener at Le Havre on Friday.

Joao Neves, who joined from Benfica for a €60million fee, has pushed Ugarte further down the pecking order. Meanwhile, HITC claims his representatives are confident the Uruguayan will complete a move to Old Trafford this summer.
Jorge Mendes is said to be trying to break the deadlock between the two clubs. Ugarte is thought to not be considering offers from elsewhere as a result as he intends to sign for the Reds.

Elsewhere, United are said to be 'intensifying their efforts' to sign Fenerbahce left-back Ferdi Kadioglu before the transfer window closes at the end of the month. With Luke Shaw sidelined with a calf injury, the club are believed to be exploring options to strengthen their left-back position.

Turkish outlet Fotospor claims United have arranged a private meeting with Kadioglu's representatives to discuss a potential move. It's said that their interest in the Turkey international is heightened by the presence of Altay Bayindir, who arrived at Old Trafford last summer.

With that said, Brighton & Hove Albion are also interested in a swoop and have reportedly made a significant offer for the defender. To get a deal over the line, United will have to match or exceed the Seagulls' offer.

headline: Man United send message to former youngster after he was hospitalised
body: Manchester United have sent a message of support to former player Angel Gomes after the midfielder was hospitalised after a collision.

The incident occurred after just 15 minutes as the 23-year-old was stretchered off after an aerial challenge with Reims defender Amadou Kone, which resulted in the player being sent off. A protective circle was formed around the former United man as he received treatment with fans from both clubs chanting his name for 10 minutes.

Thirty-four minutes were added on at the end of the first-half and Lille found of the net in stoppage time thanks to Bafode Diakite before Jonathan David wrapped up the points in added time at the end of the second-half.

United sent a message of support to their former player, they posted on X: "Sending love and strength to @AGomes_47, who has been taken to hospital following a collision while playing for Lille. We’re thinking of you, Angel."

Following the incident, Lille confirmed that he has regained consciousness and had been transferred to the hospital. Following the win, the players posed for a picture in front of the stand where the visitors were held, holding up a shirt with the message: 'Courage Angel' on the back.
Gomes is into his fourth year at Lille after being released by United in 2020. Despite joining the French club he spent a season on loan in Portugal with Boavista.
He was hailed as one of the most promising talents of this century by United's academy staff but struggled to secure a regular spot at the senior level - making just 10 senior appearances.

headline: Ex-Manchester United youngster hospitalised as game stopped for 34 minutes
body: Former Manchester United midfielder Angel Gomes has been hospitalised following a severe head injury sustained while playing for French side Lille.
The 23-year-old was contesting an aerial ball when he collided with Reims defender Amadou Kone, resulting in Kone's dismissal from the game.

Lille's squad formed a protective circle around the former United prodigy as fans from both sides chanted his name for a full 10 minutes. Gomes was subsequently stretchered off and transported by ambulance.
Lille have confirmed he has since regained consciousness and all their thoughts are with their midfielder.
An additional 34 minutes were added to the first half, with the scoreline remaining at 0-0. The match against Reims marked the start of Gomes' fourth season in Ligue 1 with Lille.

After being released by United in 2020, Gomes joined the French club before spending a season on loan in Portugal with Boavista. Despite being hailed as one of the most promising talents of this century by United's academy staff, he struggled to secure a regular spot at the senior level.
Last summer, he clinched the under-21 European Championship with England, delivering standout performances in midfield under new interim Three Lions boss Lee Carsley.

Gomes provided the joint most assists in Ligue 1 last season and has cemented himself as a key player in France. Lille went on to win 2-0 and after the match, his teammates posed with a shirt adorning the message: 'Courage Angel'.
Head coach Bruno Genesio said: "It was very hard. From the shock, I understood that it was serious. These are things that we should not see on a field.
"There are mistakes that can be excused. This one for me is not. We were very, very scared. The latest news is rather reassuring, but it is better to be careful.
"Angel asked if he was going to play on Saturday, it is a good sign if he has a sense of humor. For me the match was secondary tonight."

headline: Dan Ashworth's 'talks' about Brighton ace as Man United told £50m target is 'like no one else'
body: Former Brighton ace Glenn Murray says he once urged Manchester United sporting director Dan Ashworth to sign Joao Pedro.

Five years before he took the job at Old Trafford, Ashworth was technical director at the Amex Stadium and oversaw a period of ruthlessly shrewd business that helped establish the Seagulls as one of the most financially savvy clubs in European football.

During that period, Murray, who was on loan at Watford at the time, phoned Ashworth to tell him a young kid named Pedro, who had only just arrived in English football, was worth snapping up. Brighton never moved for the striker, but Ashworth obviously took the advice on board and tried to sign the Brazilian after becoming Newcastle's sporting director in 2022.

Speaking on the official Brighton and Hove Albion YouTube channel alongside Seagulls ace Danny Welbeck, Murray, 40, said: "I must admit, when I played with you guys with Watford, he was the one that makes you go 'Wow, who is this kid?' The things he could do, he [Pedro] was so good.

"I think there's a lot more growth in him, he has loads more to give. We've seen glimpses from last year of what he is capable of and his tally was impressive in the end. But, I think he can get so much better.

"I'll be honest, he was my first call back to Dan Ashworth. I was literally getting on the train and I was like 'You've got to sign this kid'. He was that type of player where you were just blown away by him."
Ashworth left Brighton in February 2022, and a year-and-a-half later, Pedro signed for the south coast club.

Elsewhere, United have been linked with a move for Pedro's Brighton team-mate Evan Ferguson, who notched 16 goals and five assists in his first two full seasons as a pro. The Irishman's stock has fallen slightly following an injury-disrupted 2023/24 campaign, but it's understood United are mulling over a £50million move for the striker.

Welbeck, who played 142 times for United, says he's a fervent fan of Ferguson, and lauded the youngster as a "predator in the box". He said: "Evan was unfortunate with injuries last season. It was one of them where once he gets his games this season, I'm pretty sure he will be just as lethal as he was when he came into the side.

"He's a predator in the box and there's not many like him around. He's big and strong, but he's agile and lethal in the box. I'm looking forward to seeing him back on the pitch and, obviously, we've got a lot of new players that have come into the side."

headline: Manchester United make decision on former Liverpool talent after electric start for academy
body: Manchester United youngster Ethan Ennis will not leave on loan in this transfer window.
The Manchester Evening News exclusively revealed last month that Ennis had signed a new United contract, as his previous deal with the club expired in the summer of 2025.
It's understood United have decided it's best for Ennis' development for him to spend the first half of the season with the Under-21s before the situation is assessed in January.
Ennis returned from a lengthy spell on the sidelines due to rupturing the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) in his knee in October but has impressively got back up to speed.
The youngster ended last term with a flourish and looked sharp in friendlies against Rosenborg and Rangers this summer, coming on from the bench under the eye of Erik ten Hag.
Ennis scored in the U21s' opening game of the season against Arsenal and scored again on Tuesday night when producing the goal that sparked a 3-2 comeback against Barnsley.
The 19-year-old has started the new season in great form, scoring two goals in two appearances, and his professionalism in and out of training hasn't gone unnoticed at United.

Although some speculated that Ennis would leave on loan this summer after signing his new contract, he will continue to be an integral U21 player and could be allowed to leave on a temporary deal to challenge himself in a senior environment in the January window.
There were high hopes for Ennis when United signed him from rivals Liverpool and his minutes were carefully handled last season, which helped him return to full fitness.
Ennis signed his first professional contract immediately after celebrating his 17th birthday and only the most highly regarded academy talents are given pro deals so quickly.
The Chesire-born lad scored 10 goals in 19 appearances for United's Under-18s in 2021/22, his first full season at the club, and his finishing ability is one of his finest qualities.

headline: Jack Fletcher shows why Manchester United signed him from Man City with wondergoal in comeback
body: Manchester United's Under-21s completed a stunning 3-2 comeback against Barnsley thanks to a magnificent performance from Jack Fletcher in the EFL Trophy on Tuesday night.
The EFL Trophy sees Premier League sides field U21 teams against League One and League Two senior teams, and United got their new campaign under way against Barnsley.
Barnsley took a 2-0 lead in the first half thanks to goals from Vimal Yoganathan and they looked to be on their way to a comfortable victory until a dramatic ending unfolded.

United youngster Ethan Ennis made it 2-1 with a smart finish in the 81st minute and Fletcher, who was introduced from the bench, scored a few minutes late with an unbelievable goal, striking an instinctive volley from around 35 yards that dipped under the crossbar.
Fletcher's dad, Darren Fletcher, who is a first-team coach at United, was in the stands to watch the goal and the 17-year-old celebrated wildly with the pocket of travelling supporters.
However, there was still time for a winner and Fletcher scored again in the 87th minute, cutting inside and finding the corner to complete a sensational 3-2 comeback.
Jack Fletcher signed for United from Manchester City with his twin brother Tyler Fletcher last summer and was involved in multiple first-team training sessions last season.
Darren Fletcher's sons had been in the City academy for nine years but opted to move to United and a £1.25million fee was paid to sign the pair.
Both are highly regarded and sources at United believe they have first-team potential, which saw them given their first professional contracts with the club in April.
United will also play Doncaster and Huddersfield in their EFL Trophy group and the U21 side has been followed by a sold-out away support over the last few seasons in the competition.
"My two fondest memories are the FA Youth Cup final, with the brilliant crowd that night, and Stockport away in the EFL Trophy," said U21 manager Binnion in an interview with the MEN.

"Salford was good last season, bar the result, and Fleetwood was great. Garnacho’s late winner at Barrow was great and we can’t shy away from the two drubbings against Bolton, so I’m glad we’re not in their group this year.

"But that was a great learning experience. We are very lucky to work at a football club where the academy is integral and you feel it. There’s an expectation that comes with that, but there’s excitement from the fans that I don’t see from any other club towards its youth players"

headline: 'That is utopia' - Manchester United plotting first-team debuts after historic academy season
body: Manchester United's academy building at Carrington is currently a hive of activity.
Sir Jim Ratcliffe's project to renovate the main building, which is costing £50million, began in June and the senior players are sharing the youth building while construction is ongoing.
There is a tangible buzz around the academy building and the Manchester Evening News were recently invited through its doors to speak with Under-21 manager Travis Binnion.

Binnion has been generous with his time since taking charge of the U21s and discussed the likes of Toby Collyer, Ethan Wheatley, Harry Amass, and how INEOS have impacted the academy during the interview, which was ahead of the youngsters' game against Barnsley in the EFL Trophy.

"Over the last year, those two players you mentioned, Amass and Wheatley, have progressed a lot, a hell of a lot," Binnion said. "Ethan Wheatley in particular has turned into a real eye-catching centre forward and his profile is one that managers like because he’s lean, quick and tall.
"If you drew a No.9, you’d draw him looking like Ethan, but his game has come on leaps and bounds, so knowing where to run and his link-up play has improved, and being in better positions.

"He’s spent around 12 to 13 weeks consistently training with the first-team, just like Harry, and I think within that environment, particularly when you’re having to play like they did in pre-season, you’re able to learn quicker. The good players always do in that situation.

"Equally, if you find it hard in that environment, it can be an unforgiving place to be because the level is possibly too high if you’re struggling. You find out a lot about yourself in terms of your game, but you also find out a lot about yourself as a person and as a professional as well."
Wheatley and Amass were both taken on the USA pre-season tour and were given opportunities by Erik ten Hag, who named them in a handful of first-team squads last season.
Both are highly regarded at United and Wheatley is seen as a young striker with vast potential, while some have predicted Amass could become Luke Shaw's long-term successor.
"Harry’s very good on the ball, he can defend well, but he knows a big part of his game is wider defending to ensure he deals with movement and defending space in behind," said Binnion.
"His game in possession is in a really good place and he’s physically capable, but he knows that he’s got to keep working, as most full-backs have, in their defensive moments."
Collyer was another youngster to stand out during pre-season and Ten Hag said he'd 'earned' his first-team chances when he spoke to reporters before the USA tour.

Last month, Collyer signed a new contract until 2027 and Ten Hag insisted on attending his signing ceremony at Carrington, while the Dutchman was also spotted deep in conversation with him after the FA Cup final, which was reminiscent of his exchange with Kobbie Mainoo.
Collyer's athleticism has impressed staff and his running stats are among the best in each training session, which saw him make his competitive senior debut in the Community Shield.

"If Toby had a clean 18 months and a clean two and a half years with us, we would be talking about a really top young player," Binnion said. "We’re talking about a really good young player with high potential. He joined us from another club and took a little while to get going.

"He couldn’t play in the FA Youth Cup run, so he was here but couldn’t play. He's also had a couple of injuries and nothing terrible, but when you have a spell out of the game and have a couple of injuries that stop you playing, it takes a while to get going, but when we signed him, we had no doubts about what he was capable of - he's a fantastic athlete and effective without the ball.
"Toby is also making great strides with the ball, so we’re talking there about someone who can be really effective in all moments of the game and I think that’s what you saw on tour.
"That's why the manager has involved him in numerous squads. I think he’s earned the trust of the manager and that’s not easy to do, so great credit to him, he’s a fantastic lad.

"He's got a superb attitude and he’s getting what he deserves. We just know the manager really likes him and the conversations I have with Fletch [Darren Fletcher] are along those lines and we talk about what’s right for his development, so what’s next and what does he need to do?"

Kobbe Mainoo was standing outside the academy building, chatting to Hannibal Mejbri, before Binnion arrived for the interview and the U21 boss said the next step for the likes of Wheatley, Amass and Collyer is to emulate how he's established himself as a senior player.
"The challenge for those boys is to become Kobbie, [Alejandro] Garnacho, or Omari Forson, who has left the club now but he was around a lot of matchday squads and featured more than once.

"That’s your first step, train with the first-team all the time, which some of those boys are doing, then it’s to be in multiple squads, then it’s to make multiple appearances and then become an established sort of starter. There are four stages there and that’s if you stay in the building.

"I don’t think there’s a better club in the country to be at to aspire and achieve and see very quickly what you can do. With that comes a great expectation and you’ve got to be good enough, but I really don’t think there’s a better club to be at for the ‘pathway’. People use that word and I don’t like it, but that’s the title that’s given and this is the best club to be at for that."

Mainoo and Garnacho have both previously starred in EFL Trophy fixtures, a competition in which Premier League sides field U21 teams against League One and League Two senior teams, and United get their new campaign under way on Tuesday night against Barnsley.
United will also play Doncaster and Huddersfield in their EFL Trophy group and the U21 side has been followed by a sold-out away support over the last few seasons in the competition.

"My two fondest memories are the FA Youth Cup final, with the brilliant crowd that night, and Stockport away in the EFL Trophy," said Binnion. "Salford was good last season, bar the result, and Fleetwood was great. Garnacho’s late winner at Barrow was great and we can’t shy away from the two drubbings against Bolton, so I’m glad we’re not in their group this year.

"But that was a great learning experience. We are very lucky to work at a football club where the academy is integral and you feel it. There’s an expectation that comes with that, but there’s excitement from the fans that I don’t see from any other club towards its youth players

"The EFL Trophy is the best competition for us, alongside the Youth Cup. They’re the two we’re involved in every year that I think we find the most about the players and the players look forward to most, so that’s a good indicator of the importance it plays within our programme.

"It gives the players a first taste of senior football and a real good opportunity against senior opposition, which brings different challenges, but they also have to deal with the expectation of having to deliver with a different level of challenge, which is obviously greater.

"The good players and the better players thrive in those moments, so I can remember both of those players [Mainoo and Garnacho] delivering high-level moments that gave the manager and fans insight into whether they had the capability of breaking into the first-team.

"It’s all well and good performing for the U18s or in the PL2, but there are certain games when you feel and can see in front of your eyes that players grow. On the other hand, some players don’t deliver the sort of performance you were hoping to see and that’s not terminal.
"But if over three games and two years of playing in that competition, they’ve maybe not delivered or they have, it probably points towards what they will do within the club."
Binnion last spoke to the MEN in May for a season review article and he'd just overseen an academy trip to France that saw United take on the youth team of INEOS-owned Nice.

Since then, INEOS' relationship with United's academy has strengthened and Binnion provided insight into how technical director Jason Wilcox and sporting director Dan Ashworth have been involved since joining from Southampton and Newcastle respectively.

"Dan and Jason have vast experience in the game and their relationship with Nick [Cox] and myself, along with the support from a wider perspective into recruitment from INEOS, only gives the academy more avenues to develop players and have greater depth of experience.

"I think the appointments, the resource and the experience they have, can only make the decision-making process around our players stronger. I've had meetings with both since they joined and they have been very involved in terms of supporting Nick and supporting myself.

"Whether that be from a recruitment, playing style or from a squad planning and loans perspective, they [Wilcox and Ashworth] are across all of that, so before it was [Darren] Fletch, Nick and myself. You've still got the same people involved, but there's now an extra layer from executive level, but we have football people, who have youth football experience, in those roles.

"Any level of expertise can only help us be even more aligned from academy to first-team. It will help us recruit the right players, the environment is important and the profile of our recruitment is important. If you get those right, with the right training programme, then you’ve got utopia."

Binnion had a strong working relationship with Mitchell van der Gaag, Ten Hag's former assistant manager. He departed this summer, but Darren Fletcher has been appointed as a first-team coach and the former United player is now the main conduit between the academy and first-team.
"Fletch has become even more integral in the first-team coaching set-up, so for me now, he was really important in terms of day-to-day involvement, loans and player minutes," said Binnion.

"I got close to Mitchell about what he saw each day, but with Fletch increasing his amount of coaching, I’ve kind of got one person to deal with now for almost everything, so Mitchell has gone and that’s happened, but Fletch is doing more and that’s only a good thing for our younger players."
The transfer window shuts in 10 days and a few academy players could leave on loan before the deadline. "There could and should be two or three exits on loan," said Binnion.
"I won’t say who because those players are because they could be disappointed if they stay in the building, but as I’ve stressed previously, the loans have to be right for them.
"We’ve seen previous loans of just getting the boys out of the building are not good enough. They need to get out there, play, learn and get the opportunity to develop.
"If we don’t get those opportunities, it can be a stagnant part of a player’s career, or if you get two poor loans in a row, it can be really quite detrimental to a player’s progress."

headline: Manchester United can get FFP boost at a perfect time for Sir Jim Ratcliffe
body: Manchester United could be reaping the awards in more ways than one for work done in the club’s academy over the past few years.

Head of academy Nick Cox has been praised for his work with the youth teams since being appointed into the role in the summer of 2019. The former Watford and Sheffield United man has been credited with making massive improvements in the academy, and that is now filtering into the first team.

After impressing Erik ten Hag this time last year during pre-season, midfielder Kobbie Mainoo went onto play a key role in the season. His performances earned him a call up to the England team for Euro 2024.

The 19-year-old made a total of 32 first team appearances for United in all competitions last season, scoring five goals. He was hailed for his performance in the FA Cup final against Man City as United came out as 2-1 winners.

History could potentially repeat itself again this year with both Toby Collyer and Harry Amass impressing during pre-season so far. Both players started Sunday’s 3-0 loss against Liverpool, with Amass also being selected for the 3-2 win over Real Betis as well as the friendly vs Arsenal.

Ten Hag has shown with Mainoo that he is not afraid of putting young players in if they impress. That’s a good sign for both Collyer and Amass ahead of the new season, but their development is good news for United, even if they don’t break into the first team.

Their performances mean that clubs will be willing to pay good money if they are sold now or in the future. The fact that they are both academy graduates means that any fee made will go down as pure profit on the club’s accounts.

If that is the case, then it will be a big boost for United given the Premier League’s Profitability and Sustainability Rules (PSRs). Any pure profit made will also come at a time when United need it the most, given the club's recent record on player sales and the money needed for both the new stadium and for incoming transfers.

For United it’s win-win in terms of the improvement in the academy. The club either produces players who can make their way into the first team and reduce the need for incoming transfers, or they can sell for pure profit to boost their finances.

headline: Man United star makes trophy vow after beating Man City and Chelsea rivals to 'unbelievable' award
body: England midfielder Grace Clinton says her aim is to win trophies with Manchester United after being voted PFA Young Player of the Year.

The 21-year-old joined the Reds from Everton in 2022 though she is yet to make a competitive appearance for the club, having since enjoyed loan spells at both Bristol City and Tottenham Hotspur. Clinton excelled for the latter last term, scoring four goals and assisting four others in 20 Women's Super League (WSL) appearances and playing an integral role in Spurs’ charge to their first ever Women’s FA Cup final, though she was ineligible to play against her parent club and eventual victors United at Wembley.

Her impressive form saw her receive her first senior England call up earlier this year. She made her first full start against Austria after two appearances off the bench, and duly made an impact with her first international goal in a 7-2 win for the Lionesses.

Clinton impressed so much at Tottenham that the club were keen to make her stay in the capital permanent. “She cannot stay because she’s not a part of us next year," manager Robert Vilahamn told The Athletic in April. "But if you ask me if I want to buy her, there would be a high potential I want to do that."

However United boss Skinner has always been unequivocal in his stance on the 21-year-old, insisting that her long-term future lies in Manchester. "All I hear is Tottenham want to keep Grace, of course they want to keep Grace," he said when quizzed on the club's plans for Clinton back in May. "She's a fantastic player.

"We don't get the credit that we identified her qualities at Everton, we brought her to Manchester United, gave her six months, sent her on loan at Bristol – she got experience. She then went on loan to Tottenham to get more experience. I don't think people recognise that – there is a plan for each individual we bring into the club.
"With Grace, it's absolutely worked. I want to bring her back to the club and be part of what we're doing because I think she has a huge say in how we'll play."

And Clinton has now voiced her commitment to the Reds, insisting her ambition is to add more silverware to the club's collection. "To go to Tottenham and get confidence was just amazing," she said at the start-studded awards ceremony on Tuesday night. "And to improve obviously personally. The aim is always to win trophies with Manchester United."

On her award, Clinton added: “It’s such an honour to be voted by the unbelievable players that play in this league. It’s the best league in the world. “To go out on loan, learning as a young player and being recognized is lovely. I’ve played with confidence and when you play with that then you see the best version of a player. Tottenham have been a massive part of my journey, and I can’t thank them enough. Goals and visualisation are important to me but most of all just enjoying playing. If I’m enjoying myself then I play my best football.”

Clinton also featured in the PFA Women's Team of the Year, alongside Manchester City stars Khadija 'Bunny' Shaw, Yui Hasegawa, Lauren Hemp, Khiara Keating, Alex Greenwood, Laia Aleixandri. She beat out a host of talented players to earn the award with Lauren James, Aggie Beever-Jones, Khiara Keating, Maya Le Tissier and Jess Park among the names on the Top Six shortlist.

headline: Man United have already made history but hard work is only just beginning
body: With a deft back-post finish, Lizzie Arnot wrote her name into the annals of Manchester United history. The date was August 19, 2018 and the Scotland international ensured the Reds' long-awaited renaissance began in style by netting a last-gasp winner against bitter rivals Liverpool in the League Cup.

The setting - in front of just 829 fans at an overcast Prenton Park - belied the enormity of the occassion. This was United's first competitive game in 13 years, their first competitive outing since the Glazer regime opted to disband their senior women's team after deeming it not to be part of the club's "core business".

The team was peppered with familar faces. Alex Greenwood, now captain of Manchester City, teed up Arnot to score the winner. Lauren James, who returned to childhood club Chelsea for what was - in 2021 - a British record fee, started in midfield, while current United stars Ella Toone, Millie Turner and Leah Galton also featured.
"For a team that has only been together for six weeks they weathered the storm quite well," manager Casey Stoney told BBC Radio 5 Live after the game.

"I recruited from the second tier, they've stepped up and shown they are more than capable of playing a level above that. There's no pressure from the club to get promotion but these players want to be playing in the top flight. They're history makers now."

In spite of Stoney's measured assessment of United's ambitions, the Reds did achieve promotion at the first time of asking, subsequently finishing fourth in their first season in the Women's Super League (WSL). And now, just six years on from that League Cup victory over Liverpool, United are a card-carrying member of the top flight's elite.

Stoney's departure in the summer of 2021 was a blow but her replacement, former Birmingham City boss Marc Skinner, has presided over the most successful period in the club's history. In 2022/23, the Reds took the title race to the final day, posting a club-record points tally in the process while also reaching the FA Cup final.

Last term, despite a disappointing fifth-place finish in the WSL, United beat Tottenham Hotspur to the FA Cup trophy; a reality which would have seemed inconceivable on that momentous afternoon at Prenton Park more than half a decade ago.

While the Reds have come a tremendously long way since then, it is fair to say this summer has not been without its challenges. First came the revelataion that Skinner had been handed a one-year contract extension - a decision which was not universally popular with the United fanbase.

Then came the exodus of some of the club's biggest stars. England goalkeeper Mary Earps left to join Paris Saint-Germain (PSG), citing United's transitional state and her own ambition to compete for more silverware as her chief motivating factors. Club captain Katie Zelem also departed on a free transfer, as did fan-favourite striker Lucia Garcia.

All of this unfolded has against the backdrop of Sir Jim Ratcliffe's barely concealed apathy towards Skinner's side. The INEOS chief gave a tone-deaf interview to Bloomberg, in which he conceded plans for the women's team were "TBC".

This was swiftly followed by United Women being ousted from their state-of-the-art Carrington training facility to make way for the men's team while their own building gets a revamp, though it is understood Skinner and his players will still have access to all the necessary facilities.

Still, the emergence of reports citing concern from the Professional Footballers Association (PFA) and of agents' apparent unwillingness to throw their players into the maelstrom that is Manchester United have been concerning.

That said, the Reds have recruited shrewdly in the transfer market, with the acquisition of Brighton & Hove Albion striker Elisabeth Terland and Swedish defender Anna Sandberg, in particular, inspiring excitement, while the appointment of Dan Ashworth as sporting director inspires hope of tangible change at the club.

“Delivering a successful women’s team and a thriving, productive academy are both key objectives of my job, and I have a strong background in both areas," Ashworth said in an open letter to supporters last month.

"Women’s football was an important part of my remit in past roles with Newcastle United, Brighton & Hove Albion and the FA, and it will be the same at Manchester United. Women’s football is arguably the most exciting area of growth in the global game, and we want to be part of that.
“Last season’s FA Cup win was a fantastic landmark as our first major women’s trophy, and how we want to build on that with Marc, his staff and the players."

Indeed, six years on from that win over Liverpool, United now have all the ingredients in place to be truly successful. The Reds may already have made history in the years since their reformation but, with the WSL set to be more competitive than ever next term, it is clear the hard work is only just beginning.

headline: Dan Ashworth makes encouraging Man United gesture after Sir Jim Ratcliffe admission
body: Dan Ashworth has met with Manchester United Women's players after a turbulent summer for Marc Skinner's side.

United have come in for criticism of late number after a number of high-profile players, including England goalkeeper Mary Earps and captain Katie Zelem, were allowed to leave the club on free transfers, while co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe sparked controversy when he admitted plans for the women's team were "TBC".

Fan frustration was further compounded when it emerged Skinner's side were set to be moved out of their state-of-the-art training facility to accommodate the men's team while a £50m refurbishment of their Carrington facilities was underway.

However, Ashworth's long-awaited arrival from Newcastle United last month has offered some cause for optimism, with the sporting director having previously been a huge advocate for the growth of the women's game during his time with the Magpies and in his previous role at Brighton & Hove Albion. And the 53-year-old has now met with Skinner and his players as they ramp up their pre-season preparations at St George's Park.

Pictures shared on the club's website show Ashworth giving a speech to the women's first-team squad and shaking hands with stars such as Ella Toone and Millie Turner. This comes after he outlined his vision for the Reds in an open letter to supporters.

“Delivering a successful women’s team and a thriving, productive academy are both key objectives of my job, and I have a strong background in both areas," Ashworth said last month. "Women’s football was an important part of my remit in past roles with Newcastle United, Brighton & Hove Albion and the FA, and it will be the same at Manchester United.

"Women’s football is arguably the most exciting area of growth in the global game, and we want to be part of that. Last season’s FA Cup win was a fantastic landmark as our first major women’s trophy, and how we want to build on that with Marc, his staff and the players."

headline: Manchester United confirm 'insane' summer transfer as overhaul continues
body: Manchester United have confirmed the signing of Canada international Simi Awujo on a three-year deal.

The 20-year-old midfielder joins the Reds from the United States collegiate system, where she represented the University of Southern California’s USC Trojans. Awujo made her senior international debut for Canada at 18-years-old and has 19 caps for her country to date, reaching the quarter-finals of this summer’s Paris 2024 Olympic games.

Reflecting on her move to Manchester, Awujo said: “To say that I’m a professional footballer for Manchester United is insane. I’m so excited for the season ahead, what the future holds here and just to be a red devil. I cannot wait to play in front of the great Manchester United fans.”

Manager Marc Skinner added: “Simi is an exciting young talent who we are delighted has chosen to continue her football journey with us here at Manchester United. Our wonderful fans can expect a midfielder with international pedigree, who will only develop further in our competitive English game.”

Awujo is United's fifth signing of the summer following the arrivals of Dominique Janssen, Melvine Malard, Elisabeth Terland and Anna Sandber. The Reds finished fifth in the Women's Super League (WSL) last term and won the Women's FA Cup. They will get their new campaign underway against West Ham at Old Trafford on Saturday, September 22.

headline: Mary Earps takes subtle swipe at Manchester United after PSG move
body: England goalkeeper Mary Earps says she is hoping to add "a few more trophies to the cabinet" after leaving Manchester United to join Paris Saint-Germain (PSG).

Earps joined the Reds in 2019 and helped the club win the FA Cup last year. However, the shot-stopper opted to embark on a new chapter when her contract expired in June after a disappointing Women's Super League (WSL) campaign saw United finished fifth last term - 21 points worse off than in the previous campaign.

Despite being linked with a move to Arsenal, Earps chose to join PSG, who have qualified for the Women's Champions League for six consecutive seasons. Speaking on the latest episode of the BBC's Tooney & Russo Show, Earps said she has established some "great relationships" in Manchester, but her decision to leave was fueled by "the opportunity to play for a great team in top competitions" and be "in a position to win silverware".

"It's like an itch you can never scratch enough,” Earps said. And the 31-year-old's former United teammate Ella Toone, who also plays alongside Earps for the Lionesses, was full of praise for the goalkeeper.
"She deserves everything," said Toone. "Mary's dream - and it always has been - is to play at the highest level, play in the Champions League and that's what she's done."

Earps is not the only player to have left United this summer, with captain Katie Zelem and forward Lucia Garcia also having departed. Reflecting last month on her decision to move overseas, Earps wrote on Instagram: "The club is about to undergo a period of transition, and unfortunately I don’t feel it aligns with the timing of where I’m at in my career, therefore I think now is the right time to make a change and embark on a new challenge."
